I'd like to re-raise the earlier point about using the deployed server model. You could use ansible or any other tooling to get the nodes running VxFlex OS, and then deploy openstack.

Today TripleO has two methods for deployment. It is assumed that if you use the overcloud-full image, all software is already installed (and no attempts to fetch external packaging is performed). The other way is a pre-deployed server where it is assumed the end user provides the appropriate repos and the software will be installed as necessary.

That being said, I'm not certain we would want this in tripleo itself. This can be performed as an add-on via custom services with host_prep_tasks or other methods via the deployment framework. 

I'm uncertain why this needs to be moved in-tree into tripleo rather than providing an external set of templates that can be included at deployment time.

Alex, do we have an example of how to add appropriate rpms?
And how will it work with immutable images?

We've previously documented the use of virt-customize to inject rpms into the overcloud-full image prior to their deployment.  Usually if something is actually integrated into rdo we can add it into the tripleo-puppet-elements or tripleo-image-elements to get it to be always installed. For 3rd party integrations (Which this would be), the use of virt-customize by a user prior to uploading the images to the undercloud be the only thing we have today.  That only applies to systems being scaled up or newly provisioned. updates and upgrades however still rely on a repos but usually the installation (when not using pre-deployed servers) does not actually fetch rpms from an external source at install time.

Because this is basically a 3rd party integration, we should have all the appropriate hooks in the framework to allow you to provide separate heat template rpms that should be able to be used to deploy the cluster without tightly coupling into tripleo itself.  Part of that could be scripts that provide sample roles as well as environment files to enable the various services.

As Dave noted in another patch set, we need to consider the performance impact of VxFlex and openstack services coexisting on the same nodes. Consider HCI w/ Ceph, where quite a bit of effort went into understanding how to tune things, which in turn led to the "derived parameters" effort in tripleo.
Is this done via the Ansible PB?
No, This is done by TripleO by the config action tripleo.<service>.firewall_rules where service represents vxflexos-mdm, vxflexos-lia, vxflexos-sds based upon the ports to open.

The heat stack will fail to deploy and it's up to the operator to dig through the nested stack resources to find the error.  This brings up a good point, a lot of times there is nothing meaningful in a resource failure, we should attempt to put something useful for debugging in the heat resource failure json.
I don't know a ton Ansible but will it behave idempotently in this case?  In other words it will extend a existing deployment instead of overwriting it?
Yes, there will be a separate ansible playbook which will be called when scaling up the existing environment.

So when VxFlexOS in installed on various node types will the roles_data.yaml services section for each node type/role, need to be updated adding the correct services by node type?  This would apply to both HCI/non-HCI deployment models.
Yes. The way it's currently deployed is based upon the roles_data.yaml file and how the different VxFlexOS services are mapped to nodes. This apply for both HCI/Non-HCI.
How are these configuration changes implemented/automated?
See below. It's handled by heat through templates.

I think you need to discuss performance impact on the HCI model, where nova and VxFlexOS will be competing for the host's CPU and RAM.

For HCI with ceph, tripleo implements the notion of "derived parameters" that calculates a couple of nova's THT parameters, namely NovaCPUAllocationRatio and NovaReservedHostMemory. The idea is to set aside enough resources for ceph so that ceph and nova don't starve each other.

The implementation is currently being reworked because it was originally done using mistral. See [2] for a discussion of how derived parameters will work in a post-mistral world.

wouldn't it disable package build for xenial in case if some hosts will continue to work on it?

The links directory is only used by the repo_build role to create wheels in the container they're in. But there is a sync process in repo_package_sync, that ends up copying these ubuntu-18 links to your "primary" ubuntu-16 repo_container. Later your ubuntu-16 repo_container uses these links (now pointing to ubuntu-18 builds) in it's repo_build process, and you end up deploying a keystone complaining about some crypto lib.

I think;
1) We shouldn't sync that dir. See https://review.opendev.org/#/c/712784/
2) We can prevent this nasty mix-up by separating links according to distro-arch, as is already done under pools/ and os-releases/version/
Why in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/708420/ is just "Ubuntu"?
Because I discovered and simplified it after I wrote this, good eye though ;) Will update.
Not sure it's really required
Ah, yes, recalled that part, you're right here
Not sure this segregation is relevant here. Like you'll need to check galera and rabbit for every host. Otherwise you'll have galera having single host, which is smth I'd not really appreciate.

But once you have only one single galera, which is eventually master, you get all read queries on it, and, in case of it failure (like because of OOM as of increased load) you will have to do cluster re-init or other nasty things. So I wouldn't leave single galera node...

I can't be sure about everyones complicated setups, but in the easy case of 3 infra nodes having all the containers, the "primary" for all services/containers ends up being the same host[0]. What makes these containers unique is stuff like the repo_server on it gets a lsync script, the galera_container on it is the one that's queried to check the cluster state. (Which is probably why it ends up in a cluster by itself after installation, and why rabbitmq ends up in a cluster by itself aswell.)

Yeah, this is where it gets funny. I'll try to make it clearer in the guide.

Before you finally take out the "primary", all other nodes should have been reinstalled with bionic, and happily joined back into the cluster. So you should have a working cluster of 3 galeras.

When you take out the primary, your keepalived/haproxy could/should switch to another box, your galera node count goes down to 2. On this new haproxy, your "primary" galera is down, and all traffic gets redirected to one of the others on the list. However as soon as the galera service gets installed on the "primary", even if it's not in sync with anyone, haproxy will see that it's operational and forward requests there. This is why you want to set it into MAINT. Then run the galera-install, check that your primary is in a cluster of itself, restart the mariadb.service, see that it joins the cluster with the other two, and gets all databasees populated.

Now you're back to 3 galeras, you can take it out of maint in haproxy.

This is also why you don't want to run with "upgrade_galera" or "upgrade_rabbitmq", because you're not upgrading any packages. And you don't want it to start uninstalling any packages on the working servers, which is what will happen if you set those flags.
I'd say just to run `openstack-ansible rabbitmq-install.yml -e rabbitmq_upgrade=true` - this should make lost host to re-join cluster

I just finished testing that, two rabbits in cluster unaware of the "primary", ran openstack-ansible rabbitmq-install.yml -e 'rabbitmq_upgrade=true' and it's a nope. Doesn't work. It is really bad infact. cause now the two rabbits are dead, and your primary is in a cluster with itself, and has no queues, so now everything is bad until you figure out how you recover rabbit, most likely by nuking the others or everything and trying again, then waiting for setup-openstack.yml to complete and populate the queues.

I'm gonna venture to say that running "anything"_upgrade=yes on a failed/incomplete cluster is gonna be a bad experience.

Upgrade shuts down the working nodes, while attempting to do something on the primary.

Yeah, you are probably right that it doesn't if you don't forget this node.
But I'm pretty sure it should work in case you drop server from cluster in advance.

It doesn't though. Atleast not if you skip clearing the node out from the cluster before doing this. Now you're left with two dead rabbitmq nodes that refuse to start because they think they're in a cluster with your "primary", but the primary disagrees.

cinder/common/config.py.message: What is the reason for marking this required when we have a default value supplied?

I think it's more like when you buy a "batteries included" electronic device with one of those crappy off-brand batteries--you know it will work long enough for you to get an idea of how the device works, but if you're smart you're going purchase a good battery soon.  I look at __DEFAULT__ as the Cinder version of a crappy battery.  We could just sell Cinder with the special little screwdriver you need to change the battery, but batteries included plus the screwdriver is even better.

This actually does have a function.  If you run oslo-config-generator with the --minimal option, it includes only those options that have been registered with required=True.  In order to encourage operators to actually configure this option, I think we should flag it as required.

Doesn't that kind of defeat the purpose of having a default value? Not completely, but if we are going to try to do extra work to make sure they set this to something other than __DEFAULT__, let's just get rid of the default value and make them explicitly use that if they don't want something else.
If having 'required=True' makes it so that operators are more likely to see the default_volume_type, then I think that is the way to go.  More user friendly in my opinion.
Looks like the agreement is more towards keeping it and an additional check is always better so adding that again.
See my comment on PS 14 about why I think this should be registered as 'required'.

Probably would be better not to use a Python keyword for variable name.

Makes sense but this is the type id received at L#104 and is used at L#116.
Also there are multiple occurrences in our API doing the same.
I think refactoring all the places together would be better?
I think you should also catch InvalidVolumeType here so that if default_volume_type is explicitly configured as None, we'll raise the DefaultMisconfiguredError.

I will add it but out of curiosity I've a doubt, I'm not sure how it can be configured as None, the config option is parsed as a string so if we set it to None, at L#198, the value of name is 'None' which results in volume type not found exception.
The only possible way is setting it to '' (blank string) but that also doesn't raises InvalidVolumeType exception (L#185 only checks for None and not for blank strings).

Yeah,
default_volume_type =
default_volume_type = ''
are treated as same cases with same not found error
ERROR cinder.volume.volume_types [None req-82fc21cf-777d-4fc0-ba34-b782457caaeb admin admin] Default volume type is not found. Please check default_volume_type config:: cinder.exception.VolumeTypeNotFoundByName: Volume type with name  could not be found.
Done

Your explanation makes sense, i.e., that whatever value is there will be treated as a string.  So I guess the degenerative case to consider is if someone has

  default_volume_type =

in the config file, which I think is basically what you said here, that is, setting the value to the empty string ''.

resolutions/20200803-distributed-project.message:
* It this the role also who writes the cycle highlights marketing material as well?

* Is this the role also who keeps the blueprint status, milestone targets, and other launchpad related things up to date and tidy?

I would prefer if the release liaison to keep a focus on the release duties. While cycle highlights could be indeed in there (and we should probably clarify it), the blueprint status and others listed here is not part of release liaison role, IMO. It's just fundamental things we have to do to deliver (and therefore release) software. We don't want to remove PTL so that release liaison is at the end the same thing as the PTL :) Let's distribute more and trust the teams' self-organisation.

> If it's paperwork that's not blocking work, I guess one could argue
 > "why do we do it in the first place?". I think things can evolve,

The benefit of a clean paperwork is not visible immediately but at a later time. For example when we want to have a fact based discussion about our current and past review bandwidth to plan the amount of accepted work for the future. Realizing at that point that we don't have past data is hard to fix retroactively.

 > and if some teams need the paperwork, let's keep it. If some don't,
 > good, let's get rid of it! We are all in this together, I hope we
 > can communicate changes that a project has decided to go through.
 > :)

I'm totally supportive to let every project decide how they organize themselves. If it is a conscious decision that they don't do that much paperwork then so be it. What I want to avoid is that we simply forget to do it even though we expect to have the data available later.

So if I understand correctly there are functions that the current PTLs are doing but in a distributed setup we are simply leaving them to the project team as a whole to fulfill. 

Honestly I doubt that launchpad management will be taken up by the project team in a self-organized way as this is mostly paper-work and if it is not done it does not cause immediate blockage of the ongoing work.

Thanks for adding the RFE coordinator optional role. I think that makes sure that the launchpad related work is not forgotten.

If it's paperwork that's not blocking work, I guess one could argue "why do we do it in the first place?". I think things can evolve, and if some teams need the paperwork, let's keep it. If some don't, good, let's get rid of it! We are all in this together, I hope we can communicate changes that a project has decided to go through. :)
we totally agree there :)

A team could choose to expand the release liaison role to include those responsibilities, or create additional roles.  This document is intended to assert the minimum set of roles the TC would require to consider the project a functional going concern, but is not an exhaustive list of possible roles.  This was intended to be handled by the statement "Any other responsibilities of the PTL that are not addressed in this document are left to the project teams to determine" but I also added more to the list of optional roles.
The PTL also making sure that incoming bugs are regularly triaged by the team.

I think that was my point: Neutron is proving there is a role for that, and it's rotating regularily. I definitely hope for the teams to self-organise, so that the bugs are indeed handled, not piling up and hidden under the bed.

I consider the optional roles to _not be listed_ as governance role, but as a guideline of what the teams should keep in mind and do.

> The PTL also making sure that incoming bugs are regularly triaged
 > by the team.

Sometimes; the Neutron rotating bug deputy is a counterexample.  Added to the list of possible roles.

we need TC liaison also in mandatory roles so that TC can have a single point of contact.

I would prefer that instead of contacting a single person we contact all of the people listed as mandatory liaisons.  I hold this position for two complementary reasons:

1. Since the mandatory liaisons are performing essential functions their roles are most likely to be kept fresh.  Someone whose role has no real import under normal conditions and just provides an occasional ack is more likely to be an entry that gets stale or that gets an ack even when the contributor has drifted away from the project.

2. A lack of response when contacting the required liaisons gets directly to the point of whether the project is healthy or not, or if a required liaison is missing.  Instead of creating an intermediary to delegate this check, it is simpler to measure the thing we want to measure directly.  

I think that treating the group of liaisons as a collective point of contact gets to the heart of what distributing the leadership means, and is must more likely to be a successful model.  I think that if we try this and it does not work then we can assess the viability of TC liaison but I'd prefer for that to be an iteration we come to if we find issues without one.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Cold shouldn't be a problem AFAIK because data in the swap file is effectively garbage at swapon time. For live, anything that is not mapped in the overlay hasn't been written-to by the instance, and thus isn't going to be considered valid on read yet. So I don't think there's realistically any case where a bad rebase would actually affect us.
I believe you, but it also seems like there might be a middle ground of storing them in the cache, but also just re-creating them on boot.

nova/virt/libvirt/imagecache.py.message:
I know what you're going to say but..

Is there any reason we wouldn't continue to let it collect the swap images, but not do anything with them? Meaning, basically leave everything you've removed at the top to scan/store swap images, but just remove this (and the _remove_swap_file() above) method.

I guess my revelation about the fact that this will ignore debris in the directory bothers me and this kindof extends it. We have these things formatted in a specific way so we can identify them, so I feel like we *should* identify them even if we specifically decide not to age/remove them.

So I was thinking that removing the swap case might cause them to be swept up as "unexplained", but it does not look like it will. Only images that are formatted like a base image are considered unexplained, which means any random file debris in the directory is, I guess, ignored (not even considered unexplained).

zuul/driver/github/graphql/__init__.py.message: What does this mean for the zuul user and/or operator? Should a single branch protection rule be used always? Maybe we should provide a hint to that here?
If the github ui warns too then I think this is sufficient to point people in the right direction.

The user can wrongly configure multiple patterns (since it's possible to use wildcars in the pattern) that match the same branch. This case is ambiguous (there is also a warning in the branch protection ui in github about that). In this case github uses a random matching rule so we cannot determine which one is correct.

I'm open for suggestions to better wording here.

zuul/driver/github/graphql/canmerge-lega.message: If a repo is operating on more than 100 matching refs could we potentially miss branch protections for ref 101 and beyond?

That is correct, however I've never seen branch protection patterns matching more than 100 branches yet. We'd need to implement paging to support this case. (Users still could shard the rules as a workaround).

If there is a need I'm open to extend this later in a follow up.
